thread.title: Aust stocks slightly lower at noon
thread.title_full: Aust stocks slightly lower at noon | Business Spectator

author: Michael Roddan
title: Aust stocks slightly lower at noon
text:
A surging energy sector, led by takeover target Santos, has failed to pull the Australian sharemarket higher, as mining and media stocks weigh on the bourse.
At 12.05pm (AEDT), the benchmark S&P/ASX200 index was down 5.9 points, or 0.11 per cent, to 5242.4, while the broader All Ordinaries had shed 7.1 points, or 0.13 per cent, to 5279.4.
A fire was lit under the energy sector today, after it was revealed that "ultra-high-net-worth" and sovereign wealth investment firm Scepter Partners had sought to buy oil and gas firm Santos for more than $7 billion.
Santos knocked back the offer, but the latest news of suitors' interest in companies in the sector rallied oil and gas stocks.
Energy stocks were the biggest gainers on the market, adding 2.59 per cent as a sector.
Santos soared 16.54 per cent to $6.34, while Oil Search added 1.78 per cent to $7.45.
Woodside Petroleum gained 0.39 per cent to $30.82.
However, soggy offshore leads and soft mining and media stocks were proving too much of a drag for the local index.
Chinese shares plummeted in late trade yesterday, with the Shanghai-Shenzhen CSI 300 index falling 3.6 per cent in the last two hours of the session, causing the Australian currency to drop seven-tenths of a US cent.
IG analyst Chris Weston blamed the sell-off on Sinosteel for missing an interest payment on $US315 million worth of 5-year notes.
Meanwhile, the price of iron ore extended its losing run to seven days as Chinese demand worries remain in the spotlight. The red streak has led the commodity to its lowest mark since the end of July.
Mining stocks were leading the market lower.
B HP Billiton shed 0.83 per cent to $24.03, while Rio Tinto gave up 0.3 per cent to $52.62.
Media stocks, in the consumer discretionary sector, were softer after Australian Competition and Consumer Commission announced it will not oppose a Foxtel-Ten Network tie-up.
Seven West Media plunged 7.24 per cent to 67.25c while Nine Entertainment dropped 5 per cent to $1.50.
News Corp was 1.33 per cent lower at $20.04.
Financials were largely flat.
Commonwealth Bank inched up 0.07 per cent to $75.86, while ANZ shares lost 0.26 per cent to $28.48.
National Australia Bank lifted 0.06 per cent to $31.74 while Westpac dipped 0.18 per cent to $30.695.
Consumer staples were also flat as the big supermarkets offset one another.
Woolworths gave up 0.56 per cent to $26.80, while Wesfarmers lifted 0.57 per cent to $40.93 after it lifted the lid on upbeat first-quarter sales results.
Meanwhile, Qantas slipped 1.03 per cent to $3.86, while Telstra added 0.27 per cent to $5.485.
Meanwhile, business conditions rose to highest point in seven years in September, according to NAB's quarterly survey, which said the economic outlook was "notably better".
In Australia, the market on Wednesday lifted modestly as investors gained confidence while waiting for a catalyst for stronger movement.
